text_eng:
Traditional Village hotel in walking distance to Scotland's largest undercover shopping and leisure centre in East Kilbride. 
Built in 1773 by General Stuart of Torrance as a cotton-spinning mill and workers' houses the building in Torrance Square provided a focus for town life. In its many incarnations the popular Torrance Hotel has also housed a school, a shop and a Coaching Inn, but it has always been at the heart of East Kilbride. The building has retained all its original character and charm. 

We have 16 comfortable, modern bedrooms including the newly refurbished Honeymoon Suite. Enjoy a meal in our warm and friendly restaurant or lounge bar which caters for a wide range of food from traditional meals to bar snacks. We are a 5 minute walk from the local train station which will take you straight into Glasgow's Central Station which runs every half hour. If more information is required then do not hesitate to ask our friendly receptionist staff.
Set in a stylish modern building, this 4-star hotel serves local produce in its elegant, dark wood restaurant. Free private parking is provided and there is a contemporary bar and terrace seating area. Located on a residential road, The Torrence is 5 minutes’ walk from East Kilbride Rail Station. The East Kilbride Shopping Centre is 1 mile from The Torrance Hotel. East Kilbridge Golf Club is a 5-minute drive away. Glasgow city centre can be reached after a 25-minute drive. Large windows feature at the front of the restaurant and full English breakfasts are available. Wi-Fi can be accessed for free in public areas. There is also a 24-hour front desk. All rooms have a private bathroom with a shower and a selection of toiletries. Each room has a TV, tea and coffee making facilities and an iron and ironing board.

A grocery shop is 30 metres away, while a restaurant serving Italian cuisine is at a distance of 150 metres.The beach is filled with bars and various water sports facilities. Tennis and basketball courts can be found within 1.5 km. Scuba diving school is 2 km away. A local bus stop with frequent lines to Trogir is 200 metres away. Railway Station is a 10-minute walk away. Pleso Airport is at a distance of 17 km.

text_eng:
Weltevreden Farm originally owned by Roelof Gerhardus Badenhorst in 1861, was initially very large andthe neighbourhoods of Northcliff, Berario and Corriemoor made up the expanse of the property in 1872. The Western side was transferred into C.J. Smit's name. In the beginning of the 20th Century, the farm was divided among the children. In 1936 Mr. Theunis Cronje bought a portion  (20 hectares) from Cornelius Smit's grandchildren. Mr Cronje was the Headmaster of Fairland Laerskool (primary school). In 1951 he retired and the homestead was built, modeled off Groot Constantia in the Cape. He kept himself busy by farming flowers cut and delivered to Multiflora Flower Market in City Deep Johannesburg.Mr Cronje was one of the founders and also Director of Shipping of this Flower market for many years. This is where the names of the streets in the vecinity were derived, like the street name running in front of the guesthouse into the cul-de-sac, Calendula Avenue.
